pageContext.claim: “And I really think what we're doing there [North Korea] is very important, but we actually had to walk. But I think we had a very good meeting. In fact, when I came home they put out a statement. That actually they were willing to do much less on the sanction front, but you see that's not what happened there.”
pageContext.analysis: The North Korean foreign minister denied that Pyongyang requested the lifting of all sanctions, as Trump had claimed in his news conference before departing Hanoi. The State Department later conceded Trump was wrong. According to a senior official who briefed the media on condition he not be named because he was not authorized to discuss the negotiations publicly, the North Koreans asked only for Washington to back the lifting of United Nations Security Council sanctions imposed since March 2016 and didn’t include the other resolutions going back a decade more. What Pyongyang was seeking, he said, was the lifting of sanctions that impede the civilian economy -- not the lifting of sanctions on armaments.
